newsitem.title: BULGARIA: Thousands march in Bulgaria, talks deadlocked.
newsitem.headline: Thousands march in Bulgaria, talks deadlocked.

text.p: Thousands of protesters marched through the Bulgarian capital on Sunday to demand a general election but the ex-communist Socialist party repeated its insistence on forming a new cabinet.
Whole families with dogs and children took to the streets, booing and whistling as they passed the cabinet building.
Bulgarian students protesting at economic hardship staged a mock emigration to western Europe, and the main opposition trade union Podkrepa called for strikes from Monday.

Students wearing signs saying "I'm emigrating, I see no alternative here" and "I'm emigrating to Albania without luggage" passed through a mock border checkpoint flying the flags of Bulgaria and the European Union, set up at the mausoleum of Bulgarian communist hero Georgi Dimitrov.
"Let them go, they had enough time to show their incompetence. We want to live here and will protest until we win," said student protester Svetla Slavova.

Bulgarian Socialist Party (BSP) leader Georgi Parvanov said the party was insisting on forming a government under Interior Minister Nikolai Dobrev, unacceptable to the opposition who hold him responsible for clashes between police and demonstrators outside parliament on the night of January 10.
"For us there is no question of giving up the nomination of Nikolai Dobrev," Parvanov said.

Despite 21 consecutive days of street protests, the Socialists kept to their insistence on forming a broad-based cabinet of technocrats, which President Petar Stoyanov has said is unlikely to win public confidence.

"The BSP is trying to ignore the protests...insisting it is able to form a government, calling it an experts' cabinet. We know that this government will be a government of the mafia," opposition leader Ivan Kostov told the crowd.
The constitution requires Stoyanov, who took office on Wednesday, to ask the Socialists as the biggest party in parliament to form a government.
Stoyanov met political leaders separately on Sunday and mediation efforts were expected to continue on Monday.
The opposition wants immediate elections, while the Socialists have proposed polls by the end of 1997 -- a year ahead of schedule.

Before and after the main news, state television journalists protesting against censorship put up a sign saying "Warning, protest action" and played the Beatles song "Let it be", a song used by anti-communist protesters in 1990.
Economists said last week Bulgaria's economy had plunged into hyper-inflation for the first time, with price rises in January expected to hit 50 percent per month.
The central bank warned that it alone could not contain the crisis and lifted administrative controls on interest rates from Monday, which economists say will boost inflation.

Bulgaria urgently needs a credible government to negotiate a new accord with the International Monetary Fund, which has suspended disbursements because the Socialist government failed to implement the last reform programme.

The national currency, the lev, dipped to new lows of 920-930 to the dollar on expectations of further political instability and the central bank fixed the currency at 813.87 for Monday, down on Friday's 731.71.
Shops have closed down as prices change within hours and impoverished consumers are buying only basic foods.

"I will keep my shop open until I sell the kitchen equipment I have already imported and then I will probably close the shop," said Ivo Milanov, an owner of a small store selling electrical appliances in central Sofia.
